title: 104_s2147
content: The Act may be cited as the "Library of Congress Bicentennial Commemorative Coin Act of 1996". Coin specifications are outlined in the Act. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint $1 silver coins and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. These coins will be legal tender as per the Act. All coins minted under this Act will be considered numismatic items as per section 5134 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary will obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins will be determined as per the Act. Design of coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of the Library of Congress, with specific inscriptions including the value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Library of Congress and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee before issuance. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single designated facility of the United States Mint. The Secretary is authorized to issue these coins only between January 1, 2000, and December 31, 2000. Additionally, the Secretary must consult with the Library of Congress for promotion and marketing purposes, and may enter into a contract with them if deemed beneficial for coin sales. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount on sale prices. All sales will include a surcharge. The Secretary will establish surcharges for all sales of coins, not exceeding $15 per $1 coin and $8 per half dollar coin. SEC. 7 of the Act waives procurement regulations for goods and services needed for the Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8 addresses the distribution of surcharges for coin sales. SEC. 8 of the Act directs all surcharges from coin sales to be promptly paid to the Library of Congress Trust Fund Board for bicentennial programs and educational outreach. The Comptroller General has the right to audit the Board's expenditures. SEC. 9 of the Act ensures that minting and issuing coins will not cost the government, requiring full payment, security, or a guarantee for each coin issued.
